headline.main-hed: SolarCity Buys Silevo, a Module Maker

alt-summary-body.p: SolarCity agreed to acquire Silevo, a maker of high-efficiency solar modules, and it wants to build a solar-panel in the U.S. that can compete head-to-head with Chinese manufacturers.

headline.main-hed: SolarCity makes acquisition with dream of big solar-panel plant in U.S.
SolarCity Makes Acquisition, Dreams of U.S. Plant -- 2nd Update
SolarCity Makes Acquisition, Dreams of U.S. Plant

summary-body.p: SolarCity agreed to acquire Silevo, a maker of high-efficiency solar modules, and it wants to build a solar-panel factory in the U.S. that can compete head-to-head with Chinese manufacturers.

headline.main-hed: SolarCity Buys Silevo, a Module Maker
headline.deck: With Acquisition, the Aim Is to Build Large Solar-Panel Plant in Buffalo

media.media-caption: SolarCity is seeking a breakthrough in the cost of solar power. Pictured, installation of solar panels in Los Angeles.

article-body.p: SolarCity Corp. agreed to acquire Silevo, a maker of high-efficiency solar modules, a move that the U.S. solar-panel installer expects will enable a breakthrough in the cost of solar power.
Based in Fremont, Calif., closely held Silevo has developed solar-cell technology with high efficiency at a low cost, SolarCity said.
Peter Rive, SolarCity's chief technology officer, compared Silevo's panels to "buying a BMW at a Ford price."

With the purchase of Silevo, SolarCity will become a manufacturer of solar modules, an industry dominated by Chinese companies and China-based manufacturers. In fact, Silevo's current manufacturing facility is based in China, but the company was developing plans for a Buffalo, N.Y., solar-module factory.

SolarCity aims to take that Buffalo plan and expand on it. With the acquisition of Silevo, SolarCity said it wants to build a solar-panel module plant in Buffalo that would triple the size of the largest solar plant in the U.S. and compete head-to-head with Chinese manufacturers.
Raymond James analysts estimate the Buffalo facility will cost between $350 million and $400 million to build, but SolarCity declined to present a price tag.
Elon Musk, SolarCity's chairman who is also chief executive of Tesla Motors, said the goal is to produce solar panels capable of generating power "cheaper than coal or fracked gas power."
SolarCity shares jumped 17.6%, or $9.65, to $64.53 in Tuesday trading.
The San Mateo, Calif., company is paying $200 million in shares for Silevo, plus another $150 million if cost and volume targets are met, Mr. Rive said.

The planned New York solar plant—which could open in two years—would produce one gigawatt of panels annually, SolarCity officials said. But the company is still in negotiations with New York state and hasn't secured a final deal to help finance construction, including low-cost government-backed bonds.

SolarCity has focused on installing and financing solar panels for homes and businesses. It generally leases its systems to homeowners rather than asking them to cover the hefty upfront costs of buying them.

SolarCity officials said they can compete by manufacturing solar modules in the U.S. because of low-cost energy to run the factory, tariffs levied on Chinese-made modules and a highly automated plant that would keep labor costs low.

Officials of SolarCity said the company is open to more acquisitions in the manufacturing space if they could help integrate the company's operations and bring down the cost of solar power on a per kilowatt-hour basis.
article-body.tagline: Tess Stynes contributed to this article.
article-body.p: Write to Russell Gold at russell.gold@wsj.com
